title: Common Text Scam Types
description: Learn about the most prevalent text message scams and how they attempt to manipulate recipients.

sections.title: Introduction to Text Scams
sections.body: Text message scams (also called 'smishing' - a combination of SMS and phishing) are becoming increasingly common as scammers look for new ways to steal personal information and money. These scams often create a false sense of urgency or curiosity to manipulate you into taking immediate action without thinking critically. Understanding the common types will help you identify and avoid them.

sections.title: Banking and Financial Scams
sections.body: Banking scams typically claim to be from your bank or financial institution and alert you to a 'problem' with your account that requires immediate attention. They may claim your account has been locked, that there's been suspicious activity, or that you need to verify a transaction.

redFlags.text: Requires urgent action to prevent negative consequences
redFlags.explanation: Real banks give you reasonable time to respond and have established secure channels for communication.
Legitimate banks typically address you by your name in communications.

redFlags.text: Includes a link to 'verify your account'
redFlags.explanation: Banks don't typically ask you to verify account details via text message links.

examples: ALERT: Your [BANK] account has been temporarily suspended due to suspicious activity. Verify your identity now: https://bank-verify.scam/login
Your recent CHASE transaction of $750 was flagged as suspicious. Confirm or deny this charge: https://chase-secure.scam/verify

sections.title: Package Delivery Scams
sections.body: Package delivery scams have become extremely common, especially as online shopping has increased. These messages claim to be from shipping companies like UPS, FedEx, or Amazon and typically state there's an issue with your delivery that needs to be resolved.

redFlags.text: Requests a small fee to release or redeliver your package
redFlags.explanation: Legitimate delivery companies don't request additional fees via text message.

redFlags.text: Refers to a package without specific order details
redFlags.explanation: Real shipping notifications include specific order information or tracking numbers you can verify.

redFlags.text: Creates urgency with phrases like 'final notice'
redFlags.explanation: Delivery companies will attempt multiple deliveries and leave physical notices, not just text messages.

examples: FedEx: Your package is pending delivery. A $2.99 fee is required for customs clearance. Pay now: https://fedex-delivery.scam/pay
USPS Notice: We attempted delivery but no one was available. Schedule redelivery here: https://usps-tracking.scam/redeliver

sections.title: Government and Tax Scams
sections.body: Government scams often claim to be from government agencies like the IRS, Social Security Administration, or other official entities. They typically threaten legal action, claim you're owed money, or state there's a problem with your benefits or tax return.

redFlags.text: Uses threatening language about legal action or arrest
redFlags.explanation: Government agencies don't threaten citizens via text message.

redFlags.text: Asks for sensitive personal information via text
redFlags.explanation: Government agencies already have your information and won't ask for it via text.

redFlags.text: Offers an unexpected refund or benefit payment
redFlags.explanation: Government refunds don't require you to click text message links.

examples: IRS ALERT: You have an unclaimed tax refund of $724.31. Claim now before it expires: https://irs-refund.scam/claim
FINAL NOTICE: Your Social Security Number has been suspended due to suspicious activity. Verify your identity: https://ssn-verify.scam/form

sections.title: Prize and Giveaway Scams
sections.body: Prize scams inform you that you've won something valuableâ€”often a contest you don't remember entering. The prize could be money, a free vacation, a new phone, or even a gift card. These scams exploit the excitement of getting something for free.

redFlags.text: Requires a fee to claim your prize
redFlags.explanation: Legitimate prizes never require upfront payment to claim.
These are invented fees designed to steal your money.

redFlags.text: Claims you were 'randomly selected' for a major prize
redFlags.explanation: If you didn't enter a contest, you can't win it.

examples: CONGRATULATIONS! You've been selected to receive a free iPhone 14! Click here to claim: https://free-iphone.scam/claim
You've won a $500 Amazon Gift Card in our monthly draw! Claim within 24hrs: https://amazon-winner.scam/redeem

quiz.question: What is a common red flag in banking scam text messages?

options.text: Including your full account number for reference
options.feedback: Banks typically show only the last few digits of your account for security reasons.

options.text: Requiring urgent action to prevent negative consequences
options.feedback: Correct! Creating a false sense of urgency is a common tactic in banking scams to pressure you into acting without thinking.

options.text: Asking you to visit your local branch in person
options.feedback: Legitimate banks might request an in-person visit for certain matters.

options.text: Providing a phone number to call that matches your bank's official number
options.feedback: Scammers typically provide fake contact information, not the official bank numbers.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a common type of text message scam?

options.text: Package delivery notifications
options.feedback: Package delivery scams are very common, especially with increased online shopping.

options.text: Banking alerts about suspicious activity
options.feedback: Banking scams are among the most common types of text message scams.

options.text: Routine appointment reminders from your doctor's office
options.feedback: Correct! While appointment reminders are legitimate messages, the other options are common scam types.

options.text: Prize or giveaway notifications
options.feedback: Prize and giveaway scams are very common text message scams.

quiz.question: In a package delivery scam, what tactic do scammers often use?

options.text: They claim your package was delivered to the wrong address
options.feedback: While this might be used, it's not the most common tactic.

options.text: They ask you to rate your delivery experience
options.feedback: Legitimate delivery services may ask for ratings, but this isn't a common scam approach.

options.text: They request a small fee to release or redeliver your package
options.feedback: Correct! Scammers often request small fees that seem reasonable, making people more likely to pay without suspicion.

options.text: They inform you that your package has been upgraded to premium shipping
options.feedback: This isn't a common tactic in delivery scams.

quiz.question: What is a key indicator of a government or tax-related scam message?

options.text: It mentions your specific tax filing status
options.feedback: Scammers typically don't have access to your specific tax details.

options.text: It uses threatening language about legal action or arrest
options.feedback: Correct! Government agencies don't threaten citizens via text message. This intimidation tactic is a clear sign of a scam.

options.text: It directs you to an official .gov website domain
options.feedback: Legitimate government communications would use .gov domains, while scammers typically use lookalike domains.

options.text: It asks you to mail in physical documents
options.feedback: Government agencies may request physical documents through official channels.

quiz.question: What should you do if you receive a text saying you've won a prize in a contest you don't remember entering?

options.text: Pay any required fees to claim your prize quickly
options.feedback: Legitimate prizes never require upfront payment to claim.

options.text: Call the provided number to verify the prize is real
options.feedback: Calling the scammer's number could lead to further scam attempts or identity theft.

options.text: Assume it's a scam and delete the message
options.feedback: Correct! If you didn't enter a contest, you can't win it. This is almost certainly a scam and should be deleted.

options.text: Reply to ask for more details about the prize
options.feedback: Engaging with scammers in any way confirms your number is active and may lead to more scam attempts.
